Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Status and Healthcare Access in the U.S.-Mexico Borderlands

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Social scientists know that access to critical services, including healthcare, depends not only on cost and availability but also on a multitude of social, cultural, and political factors. These factors include the status of those seeking care, where they live, how they interact with healthcare providers, and if they fit cultural notions of being deserving. However, what is not well understood is how these factors interact and come together in any individual's actual experience of care and its outcome. This research project will address this gap by exploring in detail the multiple pathways through which legal status affects the experiences of Latin American immigrants who seek dialysis treatment for end-stage renal disease (ESRD) in the lower Rio Grande Valley of south Texas. The research will be conducted by University of Texas at San Antonio doctoral student Milena A. Melo, under the supervision of Dr. Kathryn J. Fleuriet.

The South Texas borderlands are characterized by some of the highest rates of both poverty and undocumented residents in the country. Increasing militarization of the border has made crossing into Mexico for healthcare a virtual impossibility for undocumented immigrants. As a result, these borderlands are a particularly appropriate research site in which to pursue questions of the effects of external factors on healthcare. The particular lens through which these issues will be studied is the lived effects of immigration law and healthcare policy implementation for immigrants with different legal statuses. Methods will consist of twelve months of participant observation, surveys, and semi-structured interviews with healthcare professionals and low-income, Latin American dialysis patients. Findings from this research will contribute to understanding the relationship between normative understandings of rights, citizenship, and the social production of health disparities. While previous research has tended to generalize both the providers and the recipients of care, this project is structured to disaggregate these groups and to see how they navigate differently within the system, which will contribute to both better theory and better policy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Milena A. Melo has completed the data collection portion of her dissertation, entitled “Status and Healthcare Access in the U.S.-Mexico Borderlands,” supported by the NSF Dissertation  Improvement Grant. As a medical anthropologist, Melo examined how legal immigration status impacts the physical, emotional, and social experiences of Mexican immigrants who seek dialysis treatment for end-stage renal disease (ESRD) in the lower Rio Grande Valley of South Texas. The South Texas borderlands are characterized by some of the highest rates of poverty, diabetes, obesity, uninsured, and undocumented immigrants in the country. Militarization of the border has made crossing into Mexico for healthcare difficult for undocumented immigrants. As a result, the borderlands are a particularly appropriate research site in which to pursue questions regarding the effects of different legal statues on the experiential and relational aspects of ESRD and treatment for undocumented and documented immigrants (lawful permanent residents and naturalized citizens). Understanding the relationship between legal status, health care policy, and health outcomes helps social scientists demonstrate and explain the impact of sociocultural variables on the biological progression of disease.

 

Melo’s dissertation utilizes a comparative approach to demonstrate how different legal statuses impact access and experiences of dialysis. During her funding period, Melo spent fourteen months with healthcare professionals, immigrant dialysis patients, and patients’ families. Melo’s primary forms of data collection were interviews, case studies, and participant observation. She interviewed 42 healthcare professionals, including nurses, nephrologists, family physicians, emergency room physicians, social workers, hospital administrators, dieticians, dialysis technicians, dialysis center administrators, bio-technicians, and radiologists. In these interviews, she explored how health care providers and state policymakers accommodate and contest definitions of health citizenship and healthcare access.

 

Melo interviewed 100 Mexican immigrant dialysis patients about their illness treatment experiences. Interview topics included: experiences of dialysis, incorporating stories of access and failure to access; ideas and experiences of dialysis patient care and process; the relationship between dialysis, family, and social networks; experiences of care in their home country; impact of immigration on healthcare; and the impact of dialysis frequency on quality of life, relationships, and functional health. Her data analysis will explore the impact of policies and dialysis member’s health on family members and support networks.

 

From the dialysis patient interviews, Melo recruited eight patients to serve as case studies. Four were undocumented immigrant patients, and four were documented immigrant patients. Melo accompanied each case study during their daily activities at least twice a month for six months, including: accompanying patients to hospital emergency rooms and private clinics for dialysis, attending family gatherings such as barbecues and birthday parties, accompanying patients to doctor’s visits and other errands, and participating in informal conversations that took place around kitchen tables, front yards, and living rooms. Melo documented the social, economic, and practical complexities of dialysis patients’ daily lives within and outside of treatment, including family dynamics, class issues, risk-taking strategies, physical and emotional effects, and the ever-present reality and conversations about confronting mortality and death on a daily basis in patient lives. Melo’s dissertation ultimately contributes to theoretical conversations in cultural anthropology related to citizenship, immigration, illness experience, policy, and agency.
